The Southwest Florida Symphony presents 'Rock Star Séance'

7:30 p.m. Oct. 24. In addition to a multimedia experience, Maestro Andrew Lipke will channel the spirits of Janis Joplin, Jimi Hendrix, Kurt Cobain, Amy Winehouse, Bob Marley and more through "spirit host" vocalists/guitarists who will embody the musicians and the music they performed that changed the world. Concertgoers are encouraged to dress as their favorite dearly departed rock stars. Barbara B Mann Performing Arts Hall, 13350 FSW Parkway, Fort Myers. 239-418-0996 or https://swflso.org.

THEATER

August

Green Day's 'American Idiot'

Aug. 7-18. An energy-fueled rock opera featuring little dialogue and instead relies on the lyrics from Green Day's album to execute the story line. The Sarasota Players, 3501 S. Tamiami Trail, suite 1130, Sarasota. 941-365-2494 or www.theplayers.org.

'My Way: A Musical Tribute to Frank Sinatra'

Aug. 9-Sept. 1. With easy-going banter and 55 superbly arranged songs from the Great American Songbook, 'My Way'celebrates one of music's most iconic singers. Venice Theatre, Raymond Center, 140 Tampa Ave. W., Venice. 941-488-1115 or VeniceTheatre.org.

FST Improv — 'Comedy Lottery'

7:30 p.m. Aug. 10, 17, 24, 31 and Sept. 7, 14, 21, 28. Florida Studio Theatre, Bowne's Lab, 1265 First St., Sarasota. 941-366-9000 or www.floridastudiotheatre.org.

'Mary Poppins'

Through Aug. 10. Everyone's favorite nanny is back. Young Jane and Michael have sent many a nanny packing before Mary Poppins arrives. Using a combination of magic and common sense, she helps teach the family how to value each other again. Broadway Palm Dinner Theatre, 1380 Colonial Blvd., Fort Myers. 239-278-4422 or https://broadwaypalm.com.

'Murder On The 19th Hole'

Through Aug. 10. It's 1976 and you're invited to be a special guest at the 50th Annual Celebration of Florida's No. 1 golfing destination, Magnus Prime. You'll be given a new identity when you arrive at this very prestigious celebration. Throughout the evening, many curious events will occur, including a murder. Figure out "whodunit." Broadway Palm Dinner Theatre, Royal Palm Dining Room, 1380 Colonial Blvd., Fort Myers. 239-278-4422 or broadwaypalm.com.

Ken Ludwig's 'Dear Jack, Dear Louise'

Through Aug. 11. When two strangers meet by letter during World War II, a love story begins. U.S. Army Captain Jack Ludwig, a military doctor stationed in Oregon, begins writing to Louise Rabiner, an aspiring actress and dancer in New York City, hoping to meet her someday if the war will allow. Ludwig tells the true story of his parents' courtship, and the results are anything but expected. Florida Studio Theatre, Keating Theatre, 1241 N. Palm Ave., Sarasota. 941-366-9000 or FloridaStudioTheatre.org.

Agatha Christie's 'The Mousetrap'

Aug. 16-Sept. 21. At a secluded countryside guesthouse, seven strangers find themselves snowed in. Their predicament takes a chilling turn when a police sergeant arrives on skis, revealing there's a killer among them. As suspicion mounts, each guest unveils their murky past, adding layers of intrigue to the unfolding drama. Broadway Palm Dinner Theatre, 1380 Colonial Blvd., Fort Myers. 239-278-4422 or BroadwayPalm.com.

'The Outsider'

Through Aug. 18. Ned Newley doesn't even want to be governor. He's terrified of public speaking, and his poll numbers are impressively bad. To his ever-supportive Chief of Staff, Ned seems destined to fail. But his political consultant sees things differently: Ned might be the worst candidate ever to run for office. Unless the public is looking for. Florida Studio Theatre, Gompertz Theatre, 1265 First St., Sarasota. 941-366-9000 or FloridaStudioTheatre.org.

'The Mousetrap'

Aug. 23-Sept. 15. Agatha Christie's mystery thriller. Venice Theatre, Pinkerton Theatre, 140 Tampa Ave. W., Venice. 941-488-1115 or VeniceTheatre.org.

'The Music of Laurel Canyon' Featuring Buffalo Rhome

Through Sept 1. One of the most sacred musical places in the '60s and early '70s sits just above the Sunset Strip. Canyon became a nest of creativity, immortalizing artists like Joni Mitchell, Buffalo Springfield, Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young and The Mamas and the Papas, all of whom called the neighborhood home. Enjoy hits like "Desperado," "California Dreamin'," "Turn, Turn, Turn" and "Love the One You're With." Florida Studio Theatre, Court Cabaret, 1265 First St., Sarasota. 941-366-9000 or FloridaStudioTheatre.org.

The Four C Notes — Recreating the music of Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons

Through Oct. 13. Four guys, vintage dance moves, and a trip down memory lane with the Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons catalog. Florida Studio Theatre, Goldstein Cabaret, 1239 N. Palm Ave., Sarasota. 941-366-9000 or FloridaStudioTheatre.org.

September

'Always a Bridesmaid'

Sept. 12-22. On the night of their senior prom, Libby Ruth, Deedra, Monette and Charlie promise that they will be bridesmaids in one another's weddings. No matter what. Now, 30 years later, these Southern gals are still making "the long walk" for each other, determined to honor that vow. "For better or for worse" takes on a whole new meaning in this comedy about old friends. Charlotte Players, 1182 Market Circle, Port Charlotte. 941-255-1022 or www.charlotteplayers.org.

'Dingbat's Hercules, or, The Laborious Labors of the Artist Formerly Known as Heracles'

Sept. 20-Oct. 6. A high-energy adaptation of the Greek myth of Heracles. 'The Truth of the Night Sky: A Hermitage Collaboration'

Through Sept. 29. Multimedia artist Anne Patterson and composer Patrick Harlin, explorer of soundscape ecologies, collaborate to create an immersive installation. Visitors will plunge into color-filled light or enveloping darkness, and move in rhythm with music or ambient sound. 'Florida Highwaymen'

Through Sept. 15. The legendary Black landscape artists known as the Florida Highwaymen emerged in the 1950s in the agricultural communities of Fort Pierce and Gifford, Florida. Largely self-taught, these talented artists produced colorful scenes of Florida's unique landscapes that appealed to residents and tourists alike. Their iconic images captured the natural beauty of the Sunshine State prior to the impact of increased urbanization. Museum of Botany & the Arts, Marie Selby Botanical Gardens Downtown Sarasota campus, 1534 Mound St., Sarasota. 941-366-5731 or https://selby.org.
